key_channel_insights.line_content: OTA fares exceed Emirates website prices in 58.3% of itineraries while never undercutting, underscoring a sustained premium positioning.
MSE listings undercut Emirates website fares in 91.6% of comparisons with minimal average discounts (~0.10%), highlighting aggressive competitive pricing.
GDS shows a 64.3% premium share with an average 8% markup and negligible lower-priced offers, reinforcing its role as a higher-cost distribution channel.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: OTA fares were higher than the website for 58.3% of itineraries last week, up 0.1ppt from the prior week and 1.2ppt month-over-month.
Across all dimensions, OTA LOWER share remains at 0%, indicating the channel never undercuts the airlineâ€™s website.
Price parity (SAME) holds for 38.5% of itineraries, a slight dip of 0.1ppt week-over-week and 0.8ppt month-over-month.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: OTA N/A availability is low at 3.3% last week, essentially flat week-over-week and down 0.4ppt month-over-month.
SAME status covers 38.5% of routes last week, marginally down 0.1ppt week-over-week and 0.8ppt month-over-month.
OTA HIGHER applies to 58.3% of itineraries last week, rising 0.1ppt week-over-week and 1.2ppt month-over-month.
OTA LOWER remains at 0% across all timeframes, confirming no instances of lower OTA pricing.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: Short-haul OTA HIGHER share is 77.3% last week, slightly down 0.8ppt month-over-month but still more pronounced than long-haul.
Long-haul parity holds at 52.8% last week while OTA HIGHER share is growing, up 3.2ppt month-over-month to 42.2%.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: For AE origins, OTA HIGHER stands at 58.5% last week, down 0.5ppt month-over-month, while SAME climbs to 35.6%.
Non-AE origins show OTA HIGHER at 58.1% last week, up 3.0ppt month-over-month, as parity dips to 40.9%.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in bookings see OTA HIGHER at 58.9% last week, up 3.2ppt month-over-month, suggesting stronger late-purchase markups.
Far-out bookings have 57.4% OTA HIGHER share, down 2.3ppt month-over-month, as price parity remains near 39.8%.

mse_highlights.line_content: Emirates fares appear lower on MSE in 91.6% of comparisons last week, and this undercutting has strengthened by 2.4 percentage points month-over-month.
When MSE fares are lower they average only a 0.10% discount; premiums when higher average a similar +0.09%, indicating tight competitive margins.
Short-haul undercuts climbed by 5.7 percentage points month-over-month, raising the lower-price share to 83.3% despite slight week-over-week volatility.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: N/A status remains negligible at 0.19% last week, unchanged week-on-week and down 0.39 points versus the prior month.
Aligned fares comprise 7.87% of listings, slipping by 0.21 points week-on-week and 2.17 points month-over-month.
Lower-priced instances held at 91.55% last week, dipping 0.18 points week-on-week but rising 2.37 points from a month ago.
Higher-priced offers remain scarce at 0.38% share, up 0.19 points week-on-week and month-over-month.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: Lower-priced share hit 83.26% last week, up 5.72 points month-over-month, with average discounts of 0.18%.
Undercuts dominate at 98.58% share, flat month-over-month, delivering modest average discounts of 0.05%.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: MSE undercuts stand at 98.72% share, stable versus prior month, with an average discount of 0.05%.
Lower-price share grew to 85.96%, up 4.63 points month-over-month, delivering deeper average discounts of 0.15%.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Lower-priced offers account for 91.01%, up 2.71 points month-over-month, with average discounts of 0.11%.
Undercuts reached 92.61%, up 1.70 points month-over-month, with average discounts of 0.09%.

gds_highlights.line_content: 64.3% of fares on GDS are priced higher than the website, dwarfing the 16.3% at parity and the near-zero share of lower-priced offers.
Frequency of GDS-higher fares edged down 2.4 percentage points week-on-week and 1.3 points month-on-month, signaling a modest pullback in channel premiums.
When GDS fares exceed website prices, the average premium stands at 8%, remaining stable week-over-week and month-over-month.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 19.2% of website fares were not found on the GDS last week, up 1.9 points from the prior week and 3.2 points versus last month.
16.3% of fares show price parity with the website, a marginal 0.3-point increase week-on-week and a 1.8-point decrease month-on-month.
64.3% of offers carry a GDS premium, down 2.4 points week-on-week and 1.3 points month-on-month, with an average markup of 8%.
Fares priced lower on GDS represent just 0.2% of the total, holding flat week-on-week and month-over-month.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: 60.3% of short-haul fares on GDS are higher than website prices, yielding a substantial 16% average premium despite a slight 0.5-point weekly frequency dip.
68.1% of long-haul fares carry a GDS premium, but the average markup is just 2%, with frequency down 3.6 points week-on-week.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: 62.9% of AE-origin fares are higher on GDS at a 10% average markup, with premium frequency down over 2 points week-on-week and 3.5 points month-on-month.
65.5% of non-AE fares carry a GDS premium, stable at a 7% markup, with frequency broadly unchanged month-on-month despite a 2.6-point weekly dip.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 65.5% of close-in itineraries are more expensive on GDS, at an 8% average markup, though frequency eased 1.9 points week-on-week.
62.5% of far-out bookings are priced higher on GDS with an 8% premium, down around 2.3 points from the previous week.
